comment: This makes me wonder what Shirov had in mind that might make Kasparov change direction. This move is so out of character for Kasparov that I have doubts he has any kind of theoretical novelty; instead I think he just wants to prevent Shirov from having his way.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6
comment: This is a typical, and necessary, response to White's effort to get the central pawn duo (Pe4 & Pd4) . Black continues developing, castles and hits Pe4 to force a resolution of the central pawns.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4
comment: White threatens d4-d5 when Nc6 is awkward.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5
comment: This is the usual solution: Black fixes White's pawns and then finds some way to chip into them to open the g7-a1 diagonal again.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5 9. e5 Ne4
comment: This is risky. If Nf3 can move to allow f2-f3 then where would Ne4 run away to?

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5 9. e5 Ne4 10. Nc3
comment: I would have loved to see White find a move to challenge Ne4 with f2-f3.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5 9. e5 Ne4 10. Nc3 Bf5
comment: There are a couple of elements of this position which resemble a Slav, Exchange Variation. The main difference, of course, is the pawn at e5 rather than (say) e3. White's Bc1 can still develop freely and Bg7 is blocked, but Pd4 is also permanently weak.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5 9. e5 Ne4 10. Nc3 Bf5 11. Nh4 Be6 12. Bxc6 bxc6 13. Na4
comment: Ne4 has no easy way out. White threatens f2-f3xe4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5 9. e5 Ne4 10. Nc3 Bf5 11. Nh4 Be6 12. Bxc6 bxc6 13. Na4 g5
comment: Yes, this is ugly, but it's the only way to force Nh4 back, block Pf2 and free Bg7. It doesn't appear to hurt the safety of Kg8 since there are several pieces around him to defend. There is, however, still a possibility of Ne4 becoming stuck, as in the Kasparov-Adams game (Petrov's Def.) where Black's Qe4 got stuck.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5 9. e5 Ne4 10. Nc3 Bf5 11. Nh4 Be6 12. Bxc6 bxc6 13. Na4 g5 14. Nf3 f6 15. Be3 g4 16. Nd2 fxe5 17. Nxe4 dxe4
comment: Black's pawns look funny, but his pieces look fine.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5 9. e5 Ne4 10. Nc3 Bf5 11. Nh4 Be6 12. Bxc6 bxc6 13. Na4 g5 14. Nf3 f6 15. Be3 g4 16. Nd2 fxe5 17. Nxe4 dxe4 18. Nc5 Bf5 19. dxe5 Qxd1 20. Raxd1 Bxe5 21. Nd7
comment: If the best Kasparov can do is regain one of the bishops then he has to admit Black's success, or rather his own inability to put a dent in Shirov's fine play. This game shows Shirov's strength, despite his odd results against some of the lower-finishing players (in this event; I wouldn't rank Anand or Adams as "lower or weaker players" by any measure) .

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 g6 4. O-O Bg7 5. c3 Nf6 6. Re1 O-O 7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5 9. e5 Ne4 10. Nc3 Bf5 11. Nh4 Be6 12. Bxc6 bxc6 13. Na4 g5 14. Nf3 f6 15. Be3 g4 16. Nd2 fxe5 17. Nxe4 dxe4 18. Nc5 Bf5 19. dxe5 Qxd1 20. Raxd1 Bxe5 21. Nd7 Bxd7 22. Rxd7 Bxb2
comment: For the moment Black is ahead two pawns, but they are strew all around and weak.
